documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
The interface used for creation of the AutomatedApplicationImplementation.
Loads and starts a test application either in the current process or in a new, separate process.
The main window of the test application.
documentation.remarks: This is an AutomationElement for an OutOfProcessApplication and a System.Windows.Window for an InProcessApplication.

documentation.summary: Gets or sets the automated application implementation.
documentation.remarks: This is the 'implementation' following the bridge pattern.

documentation.summary: Indicates whether the main window of the test application is open.
Indicates whether the test application is running.
Starts the test application after validating its settings.
documentation.remarks: Refined abstractions are expected to initialize AutomatedAppImp and call AutomatedAppImp.Start().

documentation.summary: Waits for the test application to display its main window.
documentation.remarks: Blocks execution of the current thread until the window is displayed or until the specified timeout interval elapses.
documentation.param: The timeout interval.

documentation.summary: Waits for the test application to display a window with a specified name.
documentation.remarks: Blocks execution of the current thread until the window is displayed or until the specified timeout interval elapses.
documentation.param: The window to wait for.
The timeout interval.

documentation.summary: Waits for the test application to enter an idle state.
documentation.remarks: Blocks execution of the current thread until the window is displayed or until the specified timeout interval elapses.
documentation.param: The timeout interval.

documentation.summary: Adds an event handler for the given AutomatedApplicationEventType.
documentation.param: The type of event to listen for.
The delegate to be called when the event occurs.

documentation.summary: Removes an event handler for the given AutomatedApplicationEventType.
documentation.param: The type of event to remove.
The delegate to remove.

documentation.summary: Wrapper to signal the MainWindowOpened event
documentation.param: The source of the event which is IAutomatedApplicationImpl.
An System.EventArgs that contains no event data.

documentation.summary: Wrapper to signal the FocusChanged event
documentation.param: The source of the event which is IAutomatedApplicationImpl.
An System.EventArgs that contains no event data.

documentation.summary: Wrapper to signal the Exited event
documentation.param: The source of the event which is IAutomatedApplicationImpl.
An System.EventArgs that contains no event data.

documentation.summary: Notifies listeners that the MainWindow of the test application has opened.
Notifies listeners that the test application has exited.

documentation.param: The AutomatedApplication data to pass to the listeners.
The new focused element data to pass the listeners. This can be an AutomationElement for an out-of-process scenario or a UIElement for an in-process WPF scenario.

documentation.summary: The new focused element passed to the listeners.
The AutomatedApplication data passed to listeners.

Defines the contract for an AutomatedApplication.
documentation.remarks: Represents the 'Implemention' inteface for the AutomatedApplication bridge. As such, this can vary from the public interface of AutomatedApplication.

documentation.summary: The driver of the test application.

Defines the contract for creating an IAutomatedApplicationImpl instance.
Factory method for creating the IAutomatedApplicationImpl instance to be used by AutomatedApplication.
documentation.param: The settings to be passed the the implementation instance.
The AppDomain to create the implementation in. This is intended for in-proc scenarios where the AutomatedApplication needs to create the proxy in a separate AppDomain.
documentation.returns: Returns the application implementation to be used by AutomatedApplication

documentation.summary: Defines the contract for an out of process AutomatedApplication.
documentation.remarks: Represents the 'Implemention' inteface for the AutomatedApplication bridge. As such, this can vary from the public interface of AutomatedApplication.

documentation.summary: The process associated with the application.
The test application's main window opened event.
The test application's main window's focus changed event.

The application runs in-process and on a separate thread.
The application runs in-process, on a separate thread and in a separate AppDomain.
The application runs in-process and on the same thread.
Provides a base class for the functionality that all commands must implement.
Initializes a new instance of the class.

The name of the command. The base implementation is to strip off the last instance of "Command" from the end of the type name. So "DiscoverCommand" would become "Discover". If the type name does not have the string "Command" in it, then the name of the command is the same as the type name. This behavior can be overridden, but most derived classes are going to be of the form [Command Name] + Command.
Represents a dictionary that is aware of command line input patterns. All lookups for keys ignore case.
Create an empty CommandLineDictionary using the default key/value separators of '/' and '='.
Creates a dictionary using a serialization info and context. This is used for Xml deserialization and isn't normally called from user code.
documentation.param: Data needed to deserialize the dictionary.
Describes source and destination of the stream.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CommandLineDictionary class, populating a dictionary with key/value pairs from a command line that supports syntax where options are provided in the form "/key=value".
documentation.param: Key/value pairs.

documentation.summary: Creates a dictionary that is populated with key/value pairs from a command line that supports syntax where options are provided in the form "/key=value". This method supports the ability to specify delimiter characters for options in the command line.
documentation.param: Key/value pairs.
A character that precedes a key.
A character that separates a key from a value.

documentation.summary: Converts dictionary contents to a command line string of key/value pairs.
documentation.returns: Command line string.

documentation.summary: Populates a SerializationInfo with data needed to serialize the dictionary. This is used by Xml serialization and isn't normally called from user code.
documentation.param: SerializationInfo object to populate.
StreamingContext to populate data from.

documentation.summary: Provides utilities for parsing command-line values.
Sets properties on an object from a series of key/value string arguments that are in the form "/PropertyName=Value", where the value is converted from a string into the property type.
documentation.param: The object to set properties on.
The key/value arguments describing the property names and values to set.
documentation.returns: Indicates whether the properties were successfully set. Reasons for failure reasons include a property name that does not exist or a value that cannot be converted from a string.
documentation.exception: Thrown when one of the key/value strings cannot be parsed into a property.

documentation.summary: Prints names and descriptions for properties on the specified component.
documentation.param: The component to print usage for.

documentation.summary: Prints a general summary of each command.
documentation.param: A collection of possible commands.

documentation.summary: Creates a string that represents key/value arguments for the properties of the specified object. For example, an object with a name (string) of "example" and a priority value (integer) of 1 translates to '/name=example /priority=1'. This can be used to send data structures through the command line.
documentation.param: Value to create key/value arguments from.
documentation.returns: Space-delimited key/value arguments.

documentation.summary: Converter that can convert from a string to a DirectoryInfo.
Initializes a new instance of the class.
Converts from a string to a DirectoryInfo.
documentation.param: Context.
Culture.
Value to convert.
documentation.returns: DirectoryInfo, or null if value was null or non-string.

documentation.summary: Returns whether this converter can convert an object of the given type to the type of this converter, using the specified context.
documentation.param: An ITypeDescriptorContext that provides a format context.
A Type that represents the type you want to convert from.
documentation.returns: True if this converter can perform the conversion; otherwise, False.

documentation.summary: Converter that can convert from a string to a FileInfo.

Converts from a string to a FileInfo.
documentation.param: Context.
Culture.
Value to convert.
documentation.returns: FileInfo, or null if value was null or non-string.

documentation.summary: Returns whether this converter can convert an object of the given type to a FileInfo.

A Type that represents the type you want to convert from.
documentation.returns: True if this converter can perform the conversion; otherwise, False.

documentation.summary: Converts from a FileInfo to a string.
Returns whether this converter can convert a FileInfo object to the specified type.
Defines whether a property value is required to be specified.
Initializes a new instance of the class.
Contains all built-in fault injection conditions.
documentation.remarks: For more information on how to use the BuiltInConditions class, see the class. All fault injection conditions implement the interface.

documentation.summary: A built-in condition which triggers a fault every time the faulted method is called.
A built-in condition which triggers a fault the first time the faulted method is called.
A built-in condition which never triggers a fault. This condition can be used to turn off a fault rule.
A built-in condition which triggers a fault if the faulted method is called by a specified method.
documentation.param: A string in the format: System.Console.WriteLine(string), Namespace<T>.OuterClass<E>.InnerClass<F,G>.MethodName<H>(T, E, F, H, List<H>).

documentation.summary: A built-in condition which triggers a fault if the current call stack contains a specified method.
documentation.param: A string in the format: System.Console.WriteLine(string), Namespace<T>.OuterClass<E>.InnerClass<F,G>.MethodName<H>(T, E, F, H, List<H>).

documentation.summary: A built-in condition which triggers a fault after every n times the faulted method is called.
documentation.param: A positive number.
documentation.remarks: A System.Argument exception is thrown if n is not positive.

documentation.summary: A built-in condition which triggers a fault after the first n times the faulted method is called.
documentation.param: A positive number.
documentation.remarks: A System.Argument exception is thrown if n is not positive.

documentation.summary: A built-in condition which triggers a fault after the faulted method is called n times by the specified caller.
documentation.param: A positive number.
A string in the format: System.Console.WriteLine(string), Namespace<T>.OuterClass<E>.InnerClass<F,G>.MethodName<H>(T, E, F, H, List<H>).

documentation.remarks: For more information on how to use the BuiltInFaults class, see the class. All fault injection faults implement the interface.

documentation.summary: A built-in fault which returns when triggered.
documentation.remarks: This method can be called when the faulted method has a void return type; it will return null if triggered in a non-void method.

documentation.summary: A built-in fault which returns the specified object when triggered.
documentation.param: The object to return. The faulted method will return this object when the fault condition is triggered.

documentation.summary: A built-in fault which returns an object constructed according to the specified expression when triggered.
documentation.param: A string in the format: (int)3, (double)6.6, (bool)true, ‘Hello World’ which means "Hello World", System.Exception(‘This is a fault’).

documentation.summary: A built-in fault which throws the specified exception object when triggered.
documentation.param: An Exception object constructed by the process that injects the fault.
documentation.remarks: The exception object must be serializable.

documentation.summary: A built-in fault which throws an exception object constructed according to the specified expression when triggered.
documentation.param: A string in the format: System.Exception(‘This is a fault’), CustomizedNameSpace.CustomizedException(‘Error Message’, (int)3, System.Exception(‘innerException’)).

documentation.summary: Provides facilities for registration and query of the fault injection COM engine.
CLSID of the fault injection COM engine.
Registers the fault injection COM engine.
documentation.param: Path name of engine file.

documentation.summary: Unregisters the fault injection COM engine.
Supresses auto-registration behaviour of the fault injection API.
Extracts frame information from a StackTrace object.
documentation.remarks: Calling CallStack[n] (where n is zero-indexed) will return a C#-style method signature for the nth frame.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CallStack class.
documentation.param: A stack trace from which to create the CallStack.

documentation.summary: Number of Frames in the CallStack.
C#-style method signature for the specified frame.
documentation.param: frame to evaluate

documentation.summary: Calls the appropriate fault for a given faulted method.
documentation.remarks: The FaultDispatcher class contains a static method , which is called by the MSIL code, injected in the faulted method, in order to dispatch to the specific fault.

documentation.summary: Injected into the prologue of the target method.
documentation.param: Exception thrown by fault
Value to return from fault
documentation.remarks: Trap creates a RuntimeContext for the current call and evaluates the fault condition's Trigger method. If it evaluates to true the fault's Retrieve method is called.

documentation.summary: An exception that is thrown when and error in the FaultInjection API occurs.
Initializes a new instance of the FaultInjectionException class.
Initializes a new instance of the FaultInjectionException class using the specified message.
Initializes a new instance of the FaultInjectionException class using the specified message and inner exception.
Defines which method to fault, under what conditions the fault will occur, and how the method will fail. See also the class.
documentation.remarks: There can only be one fault rule per target method.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of FaultRule class with the specified method.
documentation.param: The signature of the method where the fault should be injected.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of FaultRule class with the specified method, condition and fault.
documentation.param: The signature of the method where the fault should be injected.
The condition that defines when the fault should occur.
The fault to be injected.

documentation.summary: The signature of the method where the fault should be injected.
The condition that defines when the fault should occur.
Maintains information needed for injecting faults into a test application. For general information on fault injection see this page.
documentation.remarks: Users can launch the faulted application by calling GetProcessStartInfo(string) and calling Process.Start() with the returned ProcessStartInfo.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the FaultSession class with the specified FaultRule objects.
documentation.param: FaultRule objects defining how to fault the test application.
documentation.exception: Two FaultRule objects corresponding to the same method.

documentation.summary: Directory for all log files written by applications launched by this session.
Finds the rule corresponding to a specified method.
documentation.param: The signature of the method.
documentation.returns: The FaultRule instance corresponding to the method specified. Returns null if no such rule exists.

documentation.summary: Notifies all test applications that fault rules have changed.
Creates a ProcessStartInfo with the appropriate environment variables set for fault injection.
documentation.param: The path to the executable to launch.
documentation.returns: The ProcessStartInfo object for the executable.

documentation.summary: Sets a global fault session. This enables fault injection for all .NET processes launched after the creation of the global session. This functionality is often useful when testing server .NET applications, where one application typically consists of and launches many processes.
Stores information about a faulted method.
Initializes a new instance of the RuntimeContext class.
The number of times the method has been called.
An array of C#-style method signatures for each method on the call stack.
The C#-style method signature of the caller of the faulted method.
Defines the contract for specifying when a fault will be triggered on a method.
documentation.remarks: If the fault condition is not triggered, the faulted method will execute its original code. For more information on how to use a condition, see the class.

documentation.summary: Determines whether a fault should be triggered.
documentation.param: The runtime context information for this call and the faulted method.
documentation.returns: Returns true if a fault should be triggered, otherwise returns false.

documentation.summary: Defines the contract for a fault.
documentation.remarks: For more information on how to use a fault, see the class.

documentation.summary: Defines the behavior of the fault when triggered.
documentation.param: The runtime context information for this call.
An output paramter for the exception to be thrown by the faulted method.
An output paramter for the value to be returned by the faulted method.
documentation.remarks: Parameter is only checked when returns null.

documentation.summary: Defines the contract for information provided by the faulted method.
The number of times the method is called.
An array of C#-style method signatures for each method on the call stack.
The C#-style method signature of the caller of the faulted method.
Exposes a simple interface to common keyboard operations, allowing the user to simulate keyboard input.

The key to release.

documentation.summary: Resets the system keyboard to a clean state.

The text to type.

The mouse button to click.

documentation.summary: Moves the mouse pointer to the specified screen coordinates.

The Oem comma key. ',' any country

The Oem Period key. '.' any country

A special key masking the real key being processed as a system key.
A constant reserved for future use.
Indicates the key is part of a dead-key composition
Defines values that specify the buttons on a mouse device.

Represents a snapshot in time of the memory consumed by a specified OS process. MemorySnapshot objects can be instantiated from a running process or from a file.
MemorySnapshot objects are used for detection of memory leaks.

remarks.p: For more information on memory leak detection in native code, refer to the Memory Leak Detection and Isolation article. The table below provides a relationship between the metrics reported by the different tools:

tr.td: Physical Memory : Working Set : WS Private

documentation.summary: The number of handles to GDI objects in use by the process. For more information see the GetGuiResources function.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The total number of handles currently open by the process. This number is equal to the sum of the handles currently open by each thread in this process.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The current amount of virtual memory that this process has reserved for use in the paging file or files. Those pages may or may not be in memory.
documentation.remarks:
This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:
Tool
Metric
Performance Counters
PageFileBytes
Process Explorer
n/a
Task Manager (Windows 7) n/a
For more information, see the PROCESS_MEMORY_COUNTERS_EX structure.

documentation.summary: The maximum amount of virtual memory that this process has reserved for use in the paging file or files.
documentation.remarks:
This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:
Tool
Metric
Performance Counters
PageFileBytesPeak
Process Explorer
n/a
Task Manager (Windows 7) n/a
For more information, see the PROCESS_MEMORY_COUNTERS_EX structure.

documentation.summary: The size of the nonpaged pool, an area of system memory (physical memory used by the operating system) for objects that cannot be written to disk but must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. For more information, see the GetProcessMemoryInfo function and the PROCESS_MEMORY_COUNTERS_EX structure.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The size of the paged pool, an area of system memory (physical memory used by the operating system) for objects that can be written to disk when they are not being used. For more information, see the GetProcessMemoryInfo function and the PROCESS_MEMORY_COUNTERS_EX structure.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The number of threads currently active in the process.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The time when the memory snapshot was taken.
The number of handles to USER objects in use by the process. For more information see the GetGuiResources function.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The current size of the virtual address space that the process is using. Use of virtual address space does not necessarily imply corresponding use of either disk or main memory pages. Virtual space is finite, and the process can limit its ability to load libraries. For more information see the GlobalMemoryStatusEx function and the MEMORYSTATUSEX structure. This metric is calculated as MEMORYSTATUSEX.ullTotalVirtual – MEMORYSTATUSEX.ullAvailVirtual.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The current size of memory that this process has allocated that cannot be shared with other processes. For more information see the GetProcessMemoryInfo function and the PROCESS_MEMORY_COUNTERS_EX structure (this metric corresponds to the PrivateUsage field in the structure).

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The current size of the working set of the process. The working set is the set of memory pages recently touched by the threads in the process. If free memory in the computer is above a threshold, pages are left in the working set of a process even if they are not in use. When free memory falls below a threshold, pages are trimmed from working sets. If they are needed they will then be soft-faulted back into the working set before leaving main memory.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The maximum size, in bytes, of the working set of the process at any one time. For more information see the GetProcessMemoryInfo function and the PROCESS_MEMORY_COUNTERS_EX structure.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

documentation.summary: The size of the working set that is only used for the process and not shared nor shareable by other processes. For more information see the Memory Performance Information article.

remarks.p: This metric is reported as follows by the other tools:

tr.td: Physical Memory : Working Set : WS Private

documentation.summary: Creates a MemorySnapshot instance for the specified OS process.
documentation.param: The ID of the process for which to generate the memory snapshot.
documentation.returns: A MemorySnapshot instance containing memory information for the specified process, at the time of the snapshot.

documentation.summary: Creates a MemorySnapshot instance from data in the specified file.
documentation.param: The path to the memory snapshot file.
documentation.returns: A MemorySnapshot instance containing memory information recorded in the specified file.

documentation.summary: Writes the current MemorySnapshot to a file.
documentation.param: The path to the output file.

documentation.summary: Compares the current MemorySnapshot instance to the specified MemorySnapshot to produce a difference.
documentation.param: The MemorySnapshot to be compared to.
documentation.returns: A new MemorySnapshot object representing the difference between the two memory snapshots (i.e. the result of the comparison).

documentation.summary: A collection of MemorySnapshots that can be serialized to an XML file.
documentation.example: A MemorySnapshotCollection can also be loaded from a XML file. MemorySnapshotCollection c = MemorySnapshotCollection.FromFile(@"MemorySnapshots.xml");

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
Creates a MemorySnapshotCollection instance from data in the specified file.
documentation.param: The path to the MemorySnapshotCollection file.
documentation.returns: A MemorySnapshotCollection instance, containing memory information recorded in the specified file.

documentation.summary: Writes the current MemorySnapshotCollection to a file.
documentation.param: The path to the output file.

documentation.summary: Represents one node in the object graph. The root of the graph is a graph node.
Initializes a new instance of the class.
A name to identify this node. When comparing, the left and right nodes are matched by name.
Gets the collection of child nodes to this node. The child nodes represent properties or fields on an object.
Represents the immediate parent to this node. The parent node of the root of the graph is null.
Contains the value of the object represented by this node.
Provides the System.Type of the object represented by this node. Returns null if the object value is null.
Gets the depth of this node from the root. If the depth of the root node is 0, root.child is 1.

Gets the fully qualified name of this node If the root node has a child that is named child1 and the child has another child that is named child12, qualified name of child12 would be root.child1.child12.
Performs a depth-first traversal of the graph with this node as root, and provides the nodes visited, in that order.
documentation.returns: Nodes visited in depth-first order.

documentation.summary: Represents a generic object comparer. This class uses an instance to convert objects to graph representations before comparing the representations.
documentation.remarks: Comparing two objects for equivalence is a relatively common task during test validation. One example would be to test whether a type follows the rules required by a particular serializer by saving and loading the object and comparing the two. A deep object comparison is one where all the properties and its properties are compared repeatedly until primitives are reached. The .NET Framework provides mechanisms to perform such comparisons but requires the types in question to implement part of the comparison logic (IComparable, .Equals). However, there are often types that do not follow these mechanisms. This API provides a mechanism to deep compare two objects using reflection.
documentation.example: In addition, the object comparison API allows the user to get back a list of comparison mismatches. For an example, see objects).

documentation.summary: Creates an instance of the ObjectComparer class.
documentation.param: An ObjectGraphFactory to use for converting objects to graphs.

documentation.summary: Gets the ObjectGraphFactory used to convert objects to graphs.
Performs a deep comparison of two objects.
documentation.param: The left object.
The right object.
documentation.returns: true if the objects match.

documentation.summary: Performs a deep comparison of two objects and provides a list of mismatching nodes.
documentation.param: The left object.
The right object.
The list of mismatches.
documentation.returns: true if the objects match.

documentation.summary: Creates an instance of the ObjectComparisonMismatch class.
documentation.param: The node from the left object.
The node from the right object.
Represents the type of mismatch.

documentation.summary: Gets the node in the left object.
Gets the node in the right object.
Creates a graph for the provided object.
Initializes a new instance of the class.
Creates a graph for the given object.
documentation.param: The object to convert.
documentation.returns: The root node of the created graph.

documentation.summary: Creates a graph by extracting public instance properties in the object. If the property is an IEnumerable, extract the items. If an exception is thrown when accessing a property on the left object, it is considered a match if the same exception type is thrown when accessing the property on the right object.
documentation.example: For examples, refer to .

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
Creates a graph for the given object by extracting public properties.
documentation.param: The object to convert.
documentation.returns: The root node of the created graph.

documentation.summary: The node is missing in the right graph.
The node is missing in the left graph.
The right node has fewer children than the left node.
The left node has fewer children than the right node.
The node types do not match.
The node values do not match.
Provides factory methods for generation of text, interesting from the testing point of view.
Returns a string, conforming to the provided.
documentation.param: The properties of the strings to be generated by the factory.
The random number generator seed.
documentation.returns: A string, conforming to the previously specified properties.

documentation.summary: Defines the desired properties of a character string. For more information on character strings, see this article.
documentation.remarks:
Note that this class is used as "a filter" when generating character strings with . Upon instantiation, all properties except CultureInfo of a object (which are all Nullables) have null values, which means that the object does not impose any filtering limitations on the generated strings.
Setting properties to non-null values means that the value of the property should be taken into account by during string generation. For example, setting to 10 means "generate strings with up to 10 code points".

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
Determines whether the string belongs to one or more .
Determines whether the string contains formatted numbers.
Determines whether the string is bi-directional.
Determines the type of normalization to perform on the string. For more information, see this article.
Determines the minimum number of combining marks in the string. Combining marks (and combining characters in general) are characters that are intended to modify other characters (e.g. accents, etc.)
Determines the minimum number of code points (characters) in the string.
Determines the maximum number of code points (characters) in the string.
Determines the minimum number of end-user-defined characters (EUDC) in the string.
Determines the minimum number of line breaks in the string.
Determines the minimum number of surrogate pairs in the string.
Determines the minimum number of text segmentation code points in the string.

Represents a Unicode range.
A UnicodeRange instance can be created by either providing start and end of the desired Unicode range or by providing a .
Create a UnicodeRange instance, using the provided UnicodeChart Enum type.
documentation.param: Group name of scripts, symbols or punctuations (e.g. "European Scripts", "Punctuation", etc.)

documentation.summary: Create a UnicodeRange instance, using the provided start and end of the Unicode range
documentation.param: Start of the Unicode range (e.g. 0x0000, etc.)
End of the Unicode range (e.g. 0xFFFF, etc.)
A UnicodeRange object to be copied

documentation.summary: Get the start of the Unicode range
Get the end of the Unicode range
Specifies a Unicode character code chart.
documentation.remarks: The Unicode standard defines a number of different character subsets, which are called Unicode character code charts (or Unicode charts for short). These charts are available on http://unicode.org/charts. The charts divide and categorize all symbols available in the Unicode range (0x0000 - 0x10FFFF) according to their common characteristics.

documentation.summary: Combining Diacritical Marks for Symbols Chart
Enclosed CJK Letters and Months Chart
Linear B Syllabary and Linear B Ideograms Chart
Yi Syllables and Yi Radicals Chart
Yijing Mono- Di- and Trigrams Chart
Same as Yijing Mono- Di- and Trigrams Chart

documentation.summary: Gets the color style of the theme.
Gets the IsEnabled state of the theme.

documentation.returns: Returns the current OS theme.

documentation.summary: Sets the current OS theme with the given theme parameter.
documentation.param: The theme to set the OS theme to.

documentation.summary: Sets the current OS theme with the given fileInfo parameter.
documentation.param: The fileInfo to set the theme to.

documentation.summary: Returns all the available system themes on the OS.
documentation.returns: Returns all the available system themes

documentation.summary: Represents a relationship between parameters and their values, or other constraints.
documentation.remarks: Exhaustively testing all possible inputs to any nontrivial software component is generally not possible because of the enormous number of variations. Combinatorial testing is one approach that achieves high coverage with a much smaller set of variations. Pairwise, the most common combinatorial strategy, tests every possible pair of values. Higher orders of combinations (three-wise, four-wise, and so on) can also be used for higher coverage at the expense of more variations. See Pairwise Testing and Pairwise Testing in Real World for more resources. Ideally, all parameters in a model are independent; however, this is generally not the case. Constraints define combinations of values that are impossible in the variations produced by the using combinatorial testing techniques.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
Creates a new predicate for an if-then-else constraint.
documentation.param: The test as an expression.
documentation.returns: The predicate.

documentation.param: The test as an expression.
documentation.returns: The constraint.

documentation.summary: Holds extension methods that construct if-then-else constraints.

documentation.typeparam: Type of the variation being acted on.
documentation.param: The "if" portion of the if-then.
The test of the "then".
documentation.returns: The if-then constraint.

documentation.typeparam: Type of the variation being acted on.
documentation.param: The "if-then" portion of the if-then-else.
The test of the "else".
documentation.returns: The if-then-else constraint.

documentation.summary: Contains all the parameters and constraints for the system under test, and produces a set of variations by using combinatorial testing techniques.
documentation.typeparam: The type of variations that should be generated.
documentation.example: For examples, refer to and .

documentation.summary: Initializes a new model with parameters to be inferred by reflection.
Initializes a new model with the specified parameters.

documentation.summary: The default tag for generated variations. Set this property when no value in the variation has been tagged. The default is null.

documentation.param: The order of the selected combinations (2 is every pair, 3 is every triple, and so on). Must be between 1 and the number of parameters.
documentation.returns: The variations.

documentation.summary: Generates an order-wise set of variations using the specified seed for random generation.
documentation.param: The order of the selected combinations (2 is every pair, 3 is every triple, and so on). Must be between 1 and the number of parameters.
The seed that is used for random generation.
documentation.returns: The variations.

documentation.summary: Provides a general-purpose model that generates a . See also .
documentation.remarks: Exhaustively testing all possible inputs to any nontrivial software component is generally not possible because of the enormous number of variations. Combinatorial testing is one approach to achieve high coverage with a much smaller set of variations. Pairwise, the most common combinatorial strategy, tests every possible pair of values. Higher orders of combinations (three-wise, four-wise, and so on) can also be used for higher coverage at the expense of more variations. See Pairwise Testing and Pairwise Testing in Real World for more resources.

documentation.summary: Represents a single variable and its values in the model whose values are of the specified type. Combinations of these values are used in the combinatorial generation of variations by the .
documentation.remarks: Exhaustively testing all possible inputs to any nontrivial software component is generally not possible because of the enormous number of variations. Combinatorial testing is one approach to achieve high coverage with a much smaller set of variations. Pairwise, the most common combinatorial strategy, tests every possible pair of values. Higher orders of combinations (three-wise, four-wise, and so on) can also be used for higher coverage at the expense of more variations. See Pairwise Testing and Pairwise Testing in Real World for more resources.
documentation.typeparam: The type of values that represent this parameter.

documentation.summary: The number of values in this parameter.

documentation.summary: Specifies an attribute to decorate the properties of the class that is used for generating model parameters.
documentation.remarks: When a property is decorated with a single attribute, the values from the attribute are added to the parameters that are created on the model and used for variation generation. When multiple attributes decorate the same property, a single value is selected from the values of each attribute (the number of values in the Model parameter is equal to the number of attributes that are set on the property).

documentation.summary: Instantiates an attribute with a list of values.
documentation.param: A list of values.

documentation.summary: The values that are used when generating a model parameter.
Optional. The weight to assign to a model parameter that is created based on an attribute.
Optional. The tag to assign to a model parameter that is created based on an attribute.
Represents a single value in a parameter.
Initializes a new instance of the class.
Tags the value with a user-defined expected result. At most, one tagged value appears in a variation. The default is null.
A value that indicates whether this value should be chosen more or less frequently. Larger values are chosen more often. The default is 1.0.
documentation.remarks: Weighting creates preferences for certain values. Because of the nature of the algorithm used, the actual weight has no intrinsic meaning (weighting one value at 10.0 and the others at 1.0 does not mean the first value appears 10 times more often). The primary goal of the algorithm is to cover all the combinations while using the fewest possible test cases, which often contradicts the preference for honoring the weight. Weight acts as a tie breaker when candidate values cover the same number of combinations.

documentation.summary: Returns the value that this ParameterValue represents.
documentation.returns: The value.

documentation.summary: Represents a single value in a parameter.
Initializes a new value with the specified value.
documentation.param: The value.

documentation.param: The value.
A user defined tag.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new value with the specified value and weight.
documentation.param: The value.
The weight of the value.

documentation.summary: Initializes a new value with the specified value, tag, and weight.
documentation.param: The value.

The weight of the value.

Returns the value that this ParameterValue represents.
documentation.returns: The value.

documentation.remarks: Exhaustively testing all possible inputs to any nontrivial software component is generally impossible due to the enormous number of variations. Combinatorial testing is one approach to achieve high coverage with a much smaller set of variations. Pairwise, the most common combinatorial strategy, test every possible pair of values. Higher orders of combinations (3-wise, 4-wise, etc.) can also be used for higher coverage at the expense of more variations. See Pairwise Testing and Pairwise Testing in Real World for more resources.

Represents the per-channel difference between two colors.
Initializes a new instance of the ColorDifference class using values of zero, indicating no difference.
Initializes a new instance of the ColorDifference class, using the specified alpha, red, green and blue values.
documentation.param: The alpha (transparency) color channel difference.
The red color channel difference.
The green color channel difference.
The blue color channel difference.

documentation.summary:
The Histogram class represents a histogram curve, expressed in terms of frequency (proportion of total pixels) over brightness (from 0 to 255). In other words, the Histogram class represents the percentage (proportion) of pixels that have brightness of 0, 1, etc. This page provides a good introduction to image histograms.
For testing purposes "brightness" is often equated to "difference". Thus, one is able to construct a "difference histogram" from a "difference shapshot" and compare that histogram to a histogram of "expected maximum differences" (also knows as a "tolerance histogram") in order to determine whether a visual verification test passes or fails.
A Histogram object can be loaded from a XML file or generated from a Snapshot object.

documentation.param: Which column of the histogram you want.
documentation.returns: A double value between 0 and 1.

documentation.summary: Creates a Histogram object from an existing Snapshot object.
documentation.param: The Snapshot object to derive the Histogram from.
documentation.returns: A new instance of Histogram, based on the provided snapshot.

documentation.summary: Creates a Histogram object from a histogram curve file.
documentation.param: Name of the file containing the histogram curve.
documentation.returns: A new instance of Histogram, based on the specified file.

documentation.summary: Create a snapshot to visualize this histogram, and save it to a file. The graph will be 100 pixels high and 256 columns wide - one for each 'bin' in the histogram. The snapshot generated will be framed and slightly larger.

Merges the specified input histogram curve with the current histogram by accumulating the per-brightness peak error quantities of two histograms. The Merge operation merges the peak values of the two histograms.
documentation.param: The histogram curve to be merged with.
documentation.returns: A new Histogram object, containing the peak values of both histogram curves.

documentation.summary: Saves the Histogram object to an XML file representation.
documentation.param: The path of the XML histogram file to be stored.

documentation.summary: Represents image pixels in a two-dimensional array for use in visual verification. Every element of the array represents a pixel at the given [row, column] of the image. A Snapshot object can be instantiated from a file or captured from the screen.
Returns a Color instance for the pixel at the specified row and column.
documentation.param: Zero-based row position of the pixel.
Zero-based column position of the pixel.
documentation.returns: A Color instance for the pixel at the specified row and column.

documentation.summary: Returns the width of the pixel buffer.
Returns the height of the pixel buffer.
Creates a Snapshot instance from data in the specified image file.
documentation.param: Path to the image file.
documentation.returns: A Snapshot instance containing the pixels in the loaded file.

documentation.summary: Creates a Snapshot instance populated with pixels sampled from the rectangle of the specified window.
documentation.param: The Win32 window handle (also known as an HWND), identifying the window to capture from.
Determines if window border region should captured as part of Snapshot.
documentation.returns: A Snapshot instance of the pixels captured.

documentation.summary: Creates a Snapshot instance populated with pixels sampled from the specified screen rectangle, from the context of the Desktop.
documentation.param: Rectangle of the screen region to be sampled from.
documentation.returns: A Snapshot instance of the pixels from the bounds of the screen rectangle.

documentation.summary: Instantiates a Snapshot representation from a Windows Bitmap.
documentation.param: Source bitmap to be converted.
documentation.returns: A snapshot based on the source buffer.

documentation.summary: Creates a deep-copied clone Snapshot with the same value as the existing instance.
documentation.returns: Clone instance

documentation.summary: Compares the current Snapshot instance to the specified Snapshot to produce a difference image. Note: This does not compare alpha channels.
documentation.param: The Snapshot to be compared to.
documentation.returns: A new Snapshot object representing the difference image (i.e. the result of the comparison).

documentation.summary: Compares the current Snapshot instance to the specified Snapshot to produce a difference image.
documentation.param: The target Snapshot to be compared to.
If true, compares alpha channels. If false, the alpha channel difference values are fixed to 255.
documentation.returns: A new Snapshot object representing the difference image (i.e. the result of the comparison).

documentation.summary: Draw a vertical line from the bottom of the specified column up to the height given.
documentation.param: which column to draw in
the lowest pixel of the line
the height of the line
the color of the line

documentation.summary: Writes the current Snapshot (at 32 bits per pixel) to a file.
documentation.param: The path to the output file.
The file storage format to be used.

documentation.summary: Creates a new Snapshot based on the cropped bounds of the current snapshot.
documentation.param: The bounding rectangle of the Snapshot.

documentation.summary: Creates a new Snapshot of the specified size from the original using bilinear interpolation.
documentation.param: Desired size of new image

documentation.summary: Modifies the current image to contain the result of a bitwise OR of this Snapshot and the mask. This technique can be used to merge data from two images. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitmask#Image_masks
documentation.param: Mask Snapshot to use in the bitwise OR operation.

documentation.summary: Modifies the current image to contain the result of a bitwise AND of this Snapshot and the mask. This technique can be used to remove data from an image. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitmask#Image_masks
documentation.param: Mask Snapshot to use in the bitwise AND operation.

documentation.summary: Find all instances of a subimage in this image.
documentation.param: The subimage to find in the larger image. Must be smaller than the image in both dimensions.
documentation.returns: A Collection of rectangles indicating the matching locations. If there is no match, the Collection returned will be empty.

documentation.summary: Find all instances of a subimage in this image.
documentation.param: The subimage to find in the larger image. Must be smaller than the image in both dimensions.
Custom SnapshotVerifier, used to compare the subimages.
documentation.returns: A Collection of rectangles indicating the matching locations. If there is no match, the Collection returned will be empty.

documentation.summary: Base class for all Snapshot verifier types. This establishes a single method contract: Verify(Snapshot).
Initializes a new instance of the class.
Verifies the specified Snapshot instance against the current settings of the SnapshotVerifier instance.
documentation.param: The image to be verified.
documentation.returns: The verification result based on the supplied image and the current settings of the SnapshotVerifier instance.

documentation.summary: Verifies that all pixels in a Snapshot are within tolerance range of ExpectedColor.
Initializes a new instance of a SnapshotColorVerifier class, using black pixels with zero tolerance.
Initializes a new instance of the SnapshotColorVerifier class, using the specified tolerance value.
documentation.param: The expected color to test against.
A ColorDifference instance specifying the desired tolerance.

documentation.summary: The color tolerance range for verification. To pass verification, all Snapshot pixels must be within range of the expected color tolerance.
The expected Color value for verification.
Ensures that the image colors are all within tolerance range of the expected Color.
documentation.param: The actual image being verified.
documentation.returns: A VerificationResult enumeration value based on the image, the expected color, and the tolerance.

documentation.summary:
Verifies a diffed image based on the number of pixels of a given brightness per color. A tolerance Histogram curve can be created from an XML file, produced from a reference image, or manually created for use as a tolerance.
For more information on histograms, refer to the description of .
Initializes a new instance of the SnapshotHistgramVerifier class, with the tolerance histogram curve initialized to zero tolerance for non-black values.
Initializes a new instance of the SnapshotHistgramVerifier class, with the tolerance histogram curve initialized to the specified tolerance value.
documentation.param: The tolerance Histogram to use for verification.

documentation.summary: The tolerance Histogram that is used to test snapshots; snapshots must produce a histogram which falls below this curve in order to pass.

Verifies a diffed image based on the number of pixels of a given brightness per color. A tolerance Histogram curve can be created from an XML file, produced from a reference image, or manually created for use as a tolerance.
documentation.param: The actual Snapshot to be verified.
documentation.returns: A VerificationResult enumeration value based on the image, the expected color, and the tolerance.

documentation.summary: Verifies that all pixels in a Snapshot are within the tolerance range, defined by the tolerance map.
Initializes a new instance of the SnapshotToleranceMapVerifier class, using the specified tolerance map.
documentation.param: A Snapshot instance defining the tolerance map, used by the verifier. A black tolerance map (a snapshot, where all pixels are with zero values) means zero tolerance. A white tolerance map (a snapshot, where all pixels are with value 0xFF) means infinitely high tolerance.

documentation.summary: A Snapshot defining the tolerance map used by the verifier. A black tolerance map (a snapshot, where all pixels are with zero values) means zero tolerance. A white tolerance map (a snapshot, where all pixels are with value 0xFF) means infinitely high tolerance.
Ensures that the image colors are all with smaller values than the image colors of the tolerance map.
documentation.param: The actual image being verified.
documentation.returns: A VerificationResult enumeration value based on the image, and the tolerance map.

documentation.summary: Specifies values used to report the outcome of a verification.
Object does not meet verification criteria.
WindowSnapshotMode determines if window border should be captured as part of Snapshot.
Capture a snapshot of only the window client area. This mode excludes the window border.
Capture a snapshot of the entire window area. This mode includes the window border.
The AutomationUtilities class provides a simple interface to common UI Automation (UIA) operations. The most common class of UIA operations in testing involves discovery of UI elements.
Retrieves the child element with the specified index.
documentation.param: The parent element (e.g., a ListBox control).
The index of the child element to find.
documentation.returns: An AutomationElement representing the discovered child element.

documentation.summary: Retrieves all UIA elements that meet the specified conditions.
documentation.param: Parent element, such as an application window, or AutomationElement.RootElement when searching for the application window.
Conditions that the returned collection should meet.
documentation.returns: A UIA element collection.

documentation.summary: Retrieves a UIA collection of all elements with a given class name.
documentation.param: Parent element, such as an application window, or AutomationElement.RootElement when searching for the application window.
The class name of the control type to find.
documentation.returns: A UIA element collection.

documentation.summary: Retrieves a UIA collection of all elements of a given control type.
documentation.param: Parent element, such as an application window, or AutomationElement.RootElement when searching for the application window.
Control type of the control, such as Button.
documentation.returns: A UIA element collection.

documentation.summary: Retrieves a UIA collection of all elements with a given UIA identifier.
documentation.param: Parent element, such as an application window, or AutomationElement.RootElement when searching for the application window.
UIA identifier of the searched element, such as "button1".
documentation.returns: A UIA element collection.

documentation.summary: Retrieves a UIA collection of all elements with a given name.
documentation.param: Parent element, such as an application window, or AutomationElement.RootElement when searching for the application window.
Name of the searched element, such as "button1".
documentation.returns: A UIA element collection.

documentation.summary: Helper class for the WPF Dispatcher. This class provides simple and consistent wrappers for common dispatcher operations.
This method will wait until all pending DispatcherOperations of a priority higher than the specified priority have been processed.
documentation.param: The priority to wait for before continuing.

documentation.summary: This method will wait for the specified TimeSpan, allowing pending DispatcherOperations (such as UI rendering) to continue during that time. This method should be used with caution. Waiting for time is generally discouraged, because it may have an adverse effect on the overall run time of a test suite when the test suite has a large number of tests.
documentation.param: Amount of time to wait.
